docs.lead_paragraph: When Gov. George W. Bush proposed a sweeping restructuring of the unwieldy tax code in Texas earlier this year, he pledged to spare no effort to get his bill enacted. ''I've got a lot of capital to spend,'' he said, ''and I'm going to spend every dime of it.'' To legislators, he was even more blunt, telling one, ''I'm going to kick some butts to get this thing passed.'' But with the legislative session here winding down this weekend, Mr. Bush's big plan has been killed, a stinging defeat that is the first big setback of his gubernatorial term and that also denies him what was widely seen as a possible signature accomplishment to boast about if he makes a run for the Presidency in 2000.

headline.main: Lawmakers Reject the Governor's Plan for a Sweeping Overhaul
headline.kicker: Bush Stumbles on Taxes in Texas

docs.abstract: Interview with Texas Gov George W Bush, who comments on recent defeat by lawmakers of proposal for sweeping restructuring of state's tax code; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Alarmed by a thinning of their ranks over the last two decades, unions in the New York region have stepped up recruiting efforts to a level not seen in a generation, in some cases spending 10 times what they once did to draw new members. From clerks in bookstores to limousine drivers, from Catholic school teachers to fashion models, the region's labor leaders are devoting record amounts of money and manpower to woo new workers -- and in this way are spearheading nationwide efforts to expand labor's membership and clout.

headline.main: Renewed Push in New York: More Union Cards in Wallets

docs.abstract: Labor unions in New York region have stepped up recruiting efforts to level not seen in generation, in some cases spending 10 times what they once did to draw new members; region's labor leaders are devoting record amounts of money and manpower to woo new workers--and are sprearheading nationwide efforts to expand labor's membership and clout; efforts are already paying off; labor leaders say overall surge in recruiting is helping make New York--long bastion of unionism--model for other cities; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House and Republican leaders in Congress were moving into the final stages of their negotiations to balance the Federal budget late last month, and Representative Bill Archer was out to protect his turf. Mr. Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, the crucible for all tax legislation, telephoned President Clinton, eventually reaching him in his limousine, and objected to the Administration's effort to include in the budget deal detailed tax provisions that would effectively strip Mr. Archer of his considerable power to shape the tax package.

headline.main: Texan Faces Big Challenge in Shaping Tax Policy

docs.abstract: Rep Bill Archer, Texas Republican who is chairman of House Ways and Means Committee, will have his best opportunity in coming months to put his stamp on nation's tax laws; with House Speaker Newt Gingrich politically weakened and no longer able to dictate strategy to committee chairmen as he once did, Archer will have his first real opportunity to act in tradition of past chairmen of Ways and Means Committee; his photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LAWYERLAND What Lawyers Talk About When They Talk About Law By Lawrence Joseph 225 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22. In a dictionary of quotations, the very kindest quote about lawyers comes from Oscar Wilde: ''Lawyers have been known to wrest from reluctant juries triumphant verdicts of acquittal for their clients, even when those clients, as often happens, were clearly and unmistakably innocent.'' So you brace yourself for the worst as you pick up Lawrence Joseph's new book, ''Lawyerland: What Lawyers Talk About When They Talk About Law.'' Mr. Joseph, who is himself a lawyer as well as a published poet (''Shouting at No One,'' ''Curriculum Vitae,'' ''Before Our Eyes''), apparently believes that lawyers behave among themselves differently from the way they do with people outside their profession. So he set out to meet in downtown Manhattan with as many different types of lawyers as he could find -- corporate, criminal, labor, personal injury, medical malpractice and so forth -- to get them to talk openly about their profession.

headline.main: Tort and Retort: Lawyers v. Lawyers
